messages.content: Hebrew Syntax, Morphology, and Etymology Analysis.
למנצח מזמור לדוד׃ השמים מספרים כבוד־אל ומעשה ידיו מגיד הרקיע׃

Syntax and Morphology:  - הַשָּׁמַיִם (hashamayim): 'The heavens' is a plural noun indicating the vast expanse of the sky and celestial bodies.  - מְסַפְּרִים (mesap'rim): 'declare' is a verb in the present tense, third-person plural, emphasizing continuous proclamation.  - כְּבוֹד (kavod): 'glory' is a noun conveying splendor, honor, and divine majesty.  - אֵל (El): 'God' is a singular noun denoting the Almighty.  - מַעֲשֵׂי (ma'asei): 'handiwork' is a plural noun signifying the creative works or deeds of God. Etymology:  - הַשָּׁמַיִם (hashamayim): The plural form of שָׁמַיִם (shamayim), highlighting the expansiveness and grandeur of the celestial realm.  - כְּבוֹד (kavod): Rooted in the idea of weightiness, it represents the weighty presence and honor associated with God's glory.  - אֵל (El): An ancient Semitic term for God, emphasizing divine power and authority.  - מַעֲשֵׂי (ma'asei): Derived from the root עָשָׂה (asah), signifying creative acts or accomplishments.
Hebrew Syntax, Morphology, and Etymology Analysis.
וַיֹּ֥אמֶר אֱלֹהִ֖ים יְהִ֣י א֑וֹר וַֽיְהִי־אֽוֹר׃

Syntax and Morphology:  - וַיֹּ֥אמֶר (vayomer): 'And he said' is a conjunction and a verb in the imperfect form, third-person singular, indicating God's speech.  - אֱלֹהִ֖ים (Elohim): 'God' is a singular noun referring to the Almighty.  - יְהִ֣י (yehi): 'Let there be' is a jussive verb, indicating a desire or command for light to exist.  - א֑וֹר (or): 'Light' is a noun representing illumination.  - וַֽיְהִי־אֽוֹר (vayehi-or): 'And there was light' is a conjunction, a verb in the imperfect form, and a noun, indicating the realization of God's command. Etymology:  - וַיֹּ֥אמֶר (vayomer): Derived from the root אָמַר (amar), signifying speech or expression.  - אֱלֹהִ֖ים (Elohim): An ancient Semitic term for God, emphasizing divine power and authority.  - יְהִ֣י (yehi): Rooted in the verb הָיָה (haya), expressing the idea of existence or occurrence.  - א֑וֹר (or): Associated with the concept of illumination and brightness.  - וַֽיְהִי־אֽוֹר (vayehi-or): The conjunction וַיְהִי (vayehi) introduces events and וַֽיְהִי־אֽוֹר (vayehi-or) indicates the fulfillment of God's command for light.
Hebrew Syntax, Morphology, and Etymology Analysis.
וַיַּרְא אֱלֹהִים אֶת־הָאֹור כִּי־טֹוב וַיַּבְדֵּל אֱלֹהִים בֵּין הָאֹור וּבֵין הַחֹשֶׁךְ׃

Syntax and Morphology:  - וַיַּרְא (vayar): 'And he saw' is a conjunction and a verb in the imperfect form, third-person singular, indicating God's perception.  - אֱלֹהִים (Elohim): 'God' is a singular noun referring to the Almighty.  - אֶת־הָאוֹר (et-haor): 'The light' is a direct object marker ('et') and a noun, representing illumination.  - כִּי־טוֹב (ki-tov): 'That it was good' is a conjunction, an adverb, and an adjective, expressing the positive evaluation of the light by God.  - וַיַּבְדֵּל (vayavdel): 'And he separated' is a conjunction and a verb in the imperfect form, third-person singular, indicating God's act of division.  - אֱלֹהִים (Elohim): 'God' is a singular noun referring to the Almighty.  - בֵּין הָאוֹר וּבֵין הַחֹשֶׁךְ (bein-haor uvein hachoshech): 'Between the light and between the darkness' is a preposition, two nouns, and a conjunction, describing the scope of God's separation. Etymology:  - וַיַּרְא (vayar): Derived from the root רָאָה (ra'ah), signifying perception or seeing.  - אֱלֹהִים (Elohim): An ancient Semitic term for God, emphasizing divine power and authority.  - אֶת־הָאוֹר (et-haor): The direct object marker ('et') indicates the definite direct object of the verb.  - כִּי־טוֹב (ki-tov): Rooted in the adjective טוֹב (tov), expressing goodness or desirability.  - וַיַּבְדֵּל (vayavdel): Derived from the root בָּדַל (badal), signifying separation or distinction.  - אֱלֹהִים (Elohim): An ancient Semitic term for God, emphasizing divine power and authority.  - בֵּין הָאוֹר וּבֵין הַחֹשֶׁךְ (bein-haor uvein hachoshech): The preposition בֵּין (bein) indicates a division between the two nouns, הָאוֹר (haor) and הַחֹשֶׁךְ (hachoshech).
Hebrew Syntax, Morphology, and Etymology Analysis.
סַגְלִי גָאוֹן וְעָזּוּת מִן־תּוֹרָתֶךָ כִּי חֻקֶּיךָ חָקָֽרְתִּי׃

Syntax and Morphology:  - סַגְלִי (sagli): 'My soul' is a noun indicating the inner self or life force.  - גָאוֹן (gaon): 'Arrogance' is a noun representing pride or haughtiness.  - וְעָזּוּת (ve-azu't): 'And contempt' is a conjunction and a noun, signifying disdain or scorn.  - מִן־תּוֹרָתֶךָ (min-toratekha): 'From your Torah' is a preposition, a noun, and a suffix, denoting the source of the arrogance and contempt.  - כִּי (ki): 'For' is a conjunction, indicating the reason or cause.  - חֻקֶּיךָ (chukkeikha): 'Your statutes' is a noun in the plural form, representing divine decrees or ordinances.  - חָקָֽרְתִּי (chaqarti): 'I have searched out' is a verb in the perfect form, first-person singular, indicating a thorough investigation. Etymology:  - סַגְלִי (sagli): Derived from the root סָגַל (sagal), signifying the inner self or life force.  - גָאוֹן (gaon): Rooted in the idea of exaltation, it conveys pride or haughtiness.  - וְעָזּוּת (ve-azu't): Derived from the root עָזַז (azaz), indicating strength or power, it conveys contempt or scorn.  - מִן־תּוֹרָתֶךָ (min-toratekha): The preposition מִן (min) indicates the source or origin, and תּוֹרָתֶךָ (toratekha) is derived from the root ירה (yarah), signifying instruction or teaching.  - כִּי (ki): Rooted in the idea of causation, it introduces the reason or cause.  - חֻקֶּיךָ (chukkeikha): Derived from the root חקק (chaqaq), it signifies divine decrees or ordinances.  - חָקָֽרְתִּי (chaqarti): Derived from the root חקר (chaqar), it conveys a thorough investigation or search.
Hebrew Syntax, Morphology, and Etymology Analysis.
וַיְדַבֵּ֥ר יְהוָ֖ה אֶל־מֹשֶׁ֥ה לֵּאמֹֽר׃

Syntax and Morphology:  - וַיְדַבֵּ֥ר (vay'daber): 'And the Lord spoke' is a conjunction and a verb in the imperfect form, third-person singular, indicating ongoing or habitual speech.  - יְהוָ֖ה (Yahweh): 'The Lord' is the divine name, emphasizing the personal and covenantal relationship with God.  - אֶל־מֹשֶׁ֥ה (el-Moshe): 'To Moses' is a preposition and a proper noun, indicating the recipient of the divine speech.  - לֵּאמֹֽר (le'mor): 'Saying' is a preposition and a gerund construct, introducing the content of the divine speech. Etymology:  - וַיְדַבֵּ֥ר (vay'daber): Derived from the root דָבַר (davar), it signifies speech, communication, or command.  - יְהוָ֖ה (Yahweh): The sacred name of God, indicating the eternal, self-existing God.  - אֶל־מֹשֶׁ֥ה (el-Moshe): The preposition אֶל (el) indicates direction or relation, and מֹשֶׁה (Moshe) is derived from the root משׁה (mashah), signifying drawing out or lifting out.  - לֵּאמֹֽר (le'mor): Derived from the root אמר (amar), it conveys the act of speaking or declaring.
Hebrew Syntax, Morphology, and Etymology Analysis.
וְהֵשִׁ֨יב לֵ֤ב אָבוֹת֙ עַל־בָּנִ֔ים וְלֵ֥ב בָּנִ֖ים עַל־אֲבוֹתָ֑ם פֶּן־אָב֕וֹא וְהִכֵּיתִ֥י אֶת־הָאָ֖רֶץ חֵֽרֶם׃

Syntax and Morphology:  - וְהֵשִׁ֨יב (ve'heeshiv): 'And he will turn' is a conjunction and a verb in the future tense, third-person singular, indicating a future action.  - לֵ֤ב (lev): 'The hearts' is a noun indicating the inner self or the seat of emotions.  - אָבוֹת֙ (avot): 'Fathers' is a plural noun referring to ancestors or forefathers.  - עַל־בָּנִ֔ים (al-banim): 'Upon the children' is a preposition and a plural noun, denoting descendants or offspring.  - וְלֵ֥ב (ve'lev): 'And the hearts' is a conjunction and a noun, emphasizing the continuity of the turning process.  - בָּנִ֖ים (banim): 'Children' is a plural noun indicating descendants or offspring.  - עַל־אֲבוֹתָ֑ם (al-avotam): 'Upon their fathers' is a preposition and a plural noun, denoting ancestors or forefathers.  - פֶּן־אָב֕וֹא (pen-avo): 'Lest I come' is a conjunction and a verb in the imperfect form, first-person singular, indicating a potential future action.  - וְהִכֵּיתִ֥י (ve'hiketi): 'And I will strike' is a conjunction and a verb in the future tense, first-person singular, indicating a future action.  - אֶת־הָאָ֖רֶץ (et-ha'aretz): 'The land' is a direct object marker and a noun, referring to the territory or earth.  - חֵֽרֶם (cherem): 'With a curse' is a noun indicating a divine ban or a state of dedication to destruction. Etymology:  - וְהֵשִׁ֨יב (ve'heeshiv): Derived from the root שׁוּב (shuv), it conveys the idea of turning, restoring, or repenting.  - לֵ֤ב (lev): Rooted in the idea of the inner self or the seat of emotions.  - אָבוֹת֙ (avot): Derived from the root אָב (av), signifying ancestors or forefathers.  - בָּנִ֖ים (banim): Derived from the root בֵּן (ben), indicating children or descendants.  - פֶּן־אָב֕וֹא (pen-avo): The conjunction פֶּן (pen) introduces a negative purpose, and אָבוֹא (avo) is derived from the root בוא (bo), signifying coming or entering.  - וְהִכֵּיתִ֥י (ve'hiketi): Derived from the root נכה (nakah), it conveys the idea of striking or smiting.  - אֶת־הָאָ֖רֶץ (et-ha'aretz): The direct object marker אֶת (et) indicates the definite direct object of the verb, and הָאָ֖רֶץ (ha'aretz) refers to the land or earth.  - חֵֽרֶם (cherem): Rooted in the idea of dedication to destruction or a divine ban.
Hebrew Syntax, Morphology, and Etymology Analysis.
וַיֹּ֨אמֶר יְהוָ֜ה יַֽעַן־עָזְב֤וּ אֶת־תּוֹרָתִי֙ אֲשֶׁ֣ר נָֽתַתִּי־לָהֶ֔ם וְלֹ֥א שָׁמְע֖וּ בְּקוֹלִ֑י וַיֵּלְכ֖וּ אַחֲרֵֽי־לְבַב־רוּעַ֥תָם׃

Syntax and Morphology:  - וַיֹּ֨אמֶר (vayomer): 'And the Lord said' is a conjunction and a verb in the perfect form, third-person singular, indicating a past action.  - יְהוָ֜ה (Yahweh): The divine name, emphasizing the personal and covenantal relationship with God.  - יַֽעַן־עָזְב֤וּ (ya'an-azvu): 'Because they have forsaken' is a conjunction, a verb in the perfect form, third-person plural, and a direct object marker, indicating the cause of the action.  - אֶת־תּוֹרָתִי֙ (et-torati): 'My law' is a direct object marker and a noun, representing God's instruction or teaching.  - אֲשֶׁ֣ר נָֽתַתִּי־לָהֶ֔ם (asher natati-lahem): 'That I gave to them' is a relative pronoun, a verb in the perfect form, first-person singular, and a direct object marker, indicating the origin of the law.  - וְלֹ֥א שָׁמְעוּ (ve-lo shamu): 'And they did not listen' is a conjunction, a verb in the perfect form, third-person plural, and a direct object marker, indicating disobedience.  - בְּקוֹלִ֑י (be'koli): 'To my voice' is a preposition and a noun, denoting God's command or communication.  - וַיֵּלְכ֖וּ (vayelechu): 'And they went' is a conjunction and a verb in the perfect form, third-person plural, indicating a past action.  - אַחֲרֵֽי־לְבַב־רוּעַ֥תָם (acharei levav-ru'atam): 'After the stubbornness of their evil heart' is a preposition, a noun, and a noun construct phrase, describing the motivation for their actions. Etymology:  - וַיֹּ֨אמֶר (vayomer): Derived from the root אמר (amar), it signifies speaking or saying.  - יְהוָ֜ה (Yahweh): The sacred name of God, indicating the eternal, self-existing God.  - יַֽעַן־עָזְב֤וּ (ya'an-azvu): יַֽעַן (ya'an) introduces a cause, and עָזְבוּ (azvu) is derived from the root עזב (azav), meaning forsaking or abandoning.  - אֶת־תּוֹרָתִי֙ (et-torati): אֶת (et) is a direct object marker, and תּוֹרָתִי (torati) is derived from the root ירה (yarah), signifying God's instruction or teaching.  - אֲשֶׁ֣ר נָֽתַתִּי־לָהֶ֔ם (asher natati-lahem): אֲשֶׁר (asher) is a relative pronoun, and נָתַתִּי (natati) is derived from the root נתן (natan), meaning giving or granting.  - וְלֹ֥א שָׁמְעוּ (ve-lo shamu): וְלֹ֥א (ve-lo) is a conjunction indicating negation, and שָׁמְעוּ (shamu) is derived from the root שׁמע (shama'), signifying listening or obeying.  - בְּקוֹלִ֑י (be'koli): בְּ (be) is a preposition, and קוֹלִי (koli) is derived from the root קל (qol), meaning voice or sound.  - וַיֵּלְכ֖וּ (vayelechu): Derived from the root הלך (halak), it conveys the idea of going or walking.  - אַחֲרֵֽי־לְבַב־רוּעַ֥תָם (acharei levav-ru'atam): אַחֲרֵי (acharei) is a preposition indicating 'after,' and לְבַב (levav) is a noun meaning heart. רוּעַ֥תָם (ru'atam) is derived from the root רָעַע (ra'a), signifying evil or wickedness.
Hebrew Syntax, Morphology, and Etymology Analysis.
אַחַ֥ר ׀ כֵּֽן־בָּֽאוּ֮ כֹּ֣ל ׀ אַחֹ֣ו וְכֹ֣ל בֵּ֠יתוֹ יַֽחַיּוּ׃

Syntax and Morphology:  - אַחַ֥ר (achar): 'After' is a preposition, indicating sequence or time.  - כֵּֽן (ken): 'Thus' or 'so' is an adverb, denoting manner or consequence.  - בָּֽאוּ (ba'u): 'They came' is a verb in the perfect form, third-person plural, indicating a completed action.  - כֹּ֣ל (kol): 'All' is an adjective, indicating totality or completeness.  - אַחֹ֣ו (acho): 'His brother' is a noun, denoting a male sibling.  - וְכֹ֣ל (ve-kol): 'And all' is a conjunction and an adjective, emphasizing inclusivity.  - בֵּ֠יתוֹ (beto): 'His household' is a noun, representing a family or a household.  - יַֽחַיּוּ׃ (yachayu): 'They lived' is a verb in the imperfect form, third-person plural, indicating ongoing or future action. Etymology:  - אַחַ֥ר (achar): Derived from the root אחר (achar), it conveys the idea of being after or following.  - כֵּֽן (ken): Rooted in the root כון (kun), it signifies being in a fixed or established state.  - בָּֽאוּ (ba'u): Derived from the root בוא (bo), it means to come or enter.  - כֹּ֣ל (kol): Derived from the root כל (kol), it signifies the entirety or completeness of something.  - אַחֹ֣ו (acho): Derived from the root אח (ach), it denotes a male sibling or brother.  - וְכֹ֣ל (ve-kol): The conjunction וְ (ve) connects elements and כל (kol) means all or every.  - בֵּ֠יתוֹ (beto): Derived from the root בית (bet), it refers to a dwelling or household.  - יַֽחַיּוּ׃ (yachayu): Derived from the root חיה (chayah), it conveys the idea of living or being alive.
Hebrew Syntax, Morphology, and Etymology Analysis.
מִמִּדְבַּ֗ר וְהַלְּבָנֹ֤ון הַזֶּה֙ וְעַד־הַנָּהָ֔ר הַגָּדֹ֖ול נְהַר־פְּרָֽת׃

Syntax and Morphology:  - מִמִּדְבַּ֗ר (mim-midbar): 'From the wilderness' is a prepositional phrase, indicating origin or source.  - וְהַלְּבָנֹ֤ון (ve-ha'levanon): 'And Lebanon' is a conjunction and a proper noun, denoting a mountain range.  - הַזֶּה֙ (hazzeh): 'This' is a demonstrative adjective, indicating proximity.  - וְעַד־הַנָּהָ֔ר (ve-ad-hanahar): 'And to the river' is a conjunction and a noun phrase, specifying a geographical boundary.  - הַגָּדֹ֖ול (haggadol): 'The great' is an adjective, describing the noun 'river.'  - נְהַר־פְּרָֽת (nehar-perat): 'The river Euphrates' is a compound noun, indicating a specific river. Etymology:  - מִמִּדְבַּ֗ר (mim-midbar): Derived from the root דבר (davar), it signifies a place of barrenness or wilderness.  - וְהַלְּבָנֹ֤ון (ve-ha'levanon): Derived from the root לבן (lavan), it means white and refers to the snowy peaks of the mountain range.  - הַזֶּה֙ (hazzeh): The demonstrative adjective indicating 'this' in proximity.  - וְעַד־הַנָּהָ֔ר (ve-ad-hanahar): The conjunction וְ (ve) connects elements, and נָהָר (nahar) means river.  - הַגָּדֹ֖ול (haggadol): Derived from the root גדל (gadol), it conveys the idea of greatness or largeness.  - נְהַר־פְּרָֽת (nehar-perat): The Euphrates River, with נְהַר (nehar) meaning river and פְּרָֽת (perat) signifying fruitfulness or abundance.
Hebrew Syntax, Morphology, and Etymology Analysis.
הַקְשִׁ֗יבָה אֶל־קֹולִ֥י מַלְכִּ֑י וֵֽאלֹהַ֥י כִּֽי־אֵ֝לְךָ֗ אֶתְּפַלֵּֽל׃

Syntax and Morphology:  - הַקְשִׁ֗יבָה (haq'shivah): 'Give ear' is an imperative verb in the feminine singular, imploring attentive listening.  - אֶל־קֹולִ֥י (el-qoli): 'To the voice' is a prepositional phrase, indicating the direction of the action.  - מַלְכִּ֑י (malki): 'My King' is a possessive pronoun and a noun, expressing ownership or relationship.  - וֵֽאלֹהַ֥י (ve-Elohai): 'And my God' is a conjunction and a possessive noun, denoting ownership or relationship.  - כִּֽי־אֵ֝לְךָ֗ (ki-elecha): 'For I will pray' is a conjunction and a verb phrase, expressing purpose or intention.  - אֶתְּפַלֵּֽל (etpallel): 'I will pray' is a future tense verb, indicating the action of prayer. Etymology:  - הַקְשִׁ֗יבָה (haq'shivah): Derived from the root קשב (qashav), it means to incline or give ear.  - אֶל־קֹולִ֥י (el-qoli): The preposition אֶל (el) denotes direction, and קוֹל (qol) means voice.  - מַלְכִּ֑י (malki): Derived from the root מָלַךְ (malak), it signifies kingship or royalty.  - וֵֽאלֹהַ֥י (ve-Elohai): The conjunction וְ (ve) connects elements, and אֱלֹהַי (Elohai) denotes possession or relationship.  - כִּֽי־אֵ֝לְךָ֗ (ki-elecha): The conjunction כִּי (ki) introduces a causal relationship, and אֵלְךָ֗ (elecha) is a verb expressing the action of walking.  - אֶתְּפַלֵּֽל (etpallel): Derived from the root פלל (palal), it means to pray or intercede.
Hebrew Syntax, Morphology, and Etymology Analysis.
הֵ֚מָּה מַלְכֵ֣ם כְּלֹא־תַ֔חְלִיטוּ שָׂ֥רֵיהֶ֖ם כְּלֹ֣א תֹאכֵ֑ל חָֽשַׁק֙ וָֽעָנ֔וּ מֹֽשְׁבֹתֵיהֶ֖ם׃

Syntax and Morphology:  - הֵ֚מָּה (hemmah): 'They' is a pronoun, indicating a group of individuals or entities.  - מַלְכֵ֣ם (malkem): 'Their king' is a possessive noun, denoting ownership or relationship.  - כְּלֹא־תַ֔חְלִיטוּ (kelo-tachlitu): 'Without consultation' is a prepositional phrase, indicating the absence of consultation.  - שָׂ֥רֵיהֶ֖ם (sareihem): 'Their princes' is a possessive noun, denoting ownership or relationship.  - כְּלֹ֣א תֹאכֵ֑ל (kelo-tochel): 'You will not eat' is a negated verb phrase, expressing a prohibition.  - חָֽשַׁק֙ וָֽעָנ֔וּ (chashaq va'anu): 'Delight and respond' is a verb phrase, expressing positive emotions and actions.  - מֹֽשְׁבֹתֵיהֶ֖ם (moshvoteihem): 'Their thrones' is a possessive noun, denoting ownership or relationship. Etymology:  - הֵ֚מָּה (hemmah): A pronoun indicating a group, derived from the root הָמָה (hamah), expressing collective identity.  - מַלְכֵ֣ם (malkem): Possessive noun derived from the root מָלַךְ (malak), signifying kingship or royalty.  - כְּלֹא־תַ֔חְלִיטוּ (kelo-tachlitu): A prepositional phrase composed of כְּלֹא (k'lo) meaning 'without' and תַּחְלִיטוּ (tachlitu) meaning 'consultation.'  - שָׂ֥רֵיהֶ֖ם (sareihem): Possessive noun derived from שַׂר (sar), denoting leaders or princes.  - כְּלֹ֣א תֹאכֵ֑ל (kelo-tochel): A negated verb phrase composed of כְּלֹא (k'lo) meaning 'not' and תֹאכֵל (tochel) meaning 'eat.'  - חָֽשַׁק֙ וָֽעָנ֔וּ (chashaq va'anu): A verb phrase denoting 'delight and respond,' derived from the roots חָשַׁק (chashaq) and עָנָה (anah).  - מֹֽשְׁבֹתֵיהֶ֖ם (moshvoteihem): Possessive noun derived from the root יָשַׁב (yashav), signifying thrones or seats.
Hebrew Syntax, Morphology, and Etymology Analysis.
וַיְהִ֗י מִקֵּ֤ץ יָמִים֙ וַיָּבֵ֣א קַ֔יִן מִפְּרִ֥י הָֽאֲדָמָ֖ה מִנְחָ֣ה לַֽיהוָ֑ה׃

Syntax and Morphology:  - וַיְהִ֗י (vayehi): 'And it came to pass' is a conjunction and a verb, introducing a new development in the narrative.  - מִקֵּ֤ץ יָמִים֙ (miketz yamim): 'At the end of days' is a prepositional phrase, indicating a specific time frame.  - וַיָּבֵ֣א קַ֔יִן (vayavei Kain): 'And Cain brought' is a conjunction and a verb phrase, describing an action performed by Cain.  - מִפְּרִ֥י הָֽאֲדָמָ֖ה (mipri ha'adamah): 'From the fruit of the ground' is a prepositional phrase, specifying the origin of Cain's offering.  - מִנְחָ֣ה לַֽיהוָ֑ה (minchah laAdonai): 'An offering to the Lord' is a noun phrase, indicating the purpose of Cain's action. Etymology:  - וַיְהִ֗י (vayehi): Derived from the root הָיָה (hayah), indicating the occurrence or existence of an event.  - מִקֵּ֤ץ יָמִים֙ (miketz yamim): A prepositional phrase composed of מִקֵּץ (miketz) meaning 'at the end' and יָמִים (yamim) meaning 'of days.'  - וַיָּבֵ֣א קַ֔יִן (vayavei Kain): A conjunction and a verb phrase composed of וַיָּבֵא (vayavei) meaning 'and brought' and קַ֔יִן (Kain), the name of the person performing the action.  - מִפְּרִ֥י הָֽאֲדָמָ֖ה (mipri ha'adamah): A prepositional phrase composed of מִפְּרִי (mipri) meaning 'from the fruit' and הָֽאֲדָמָה (ha'adamah) meaning 'of the ground.'  - מִנְחָ֣ה לַֽיהוָ֑ה (minchah laAdonai): A noun phrase composed of מִנְחָה (minchah) meaning 'offering' and לַֽיהוָ֑ה (laAdonai) meaning 'to the Lord.'
